Award.AwardTitle: SEP: Earth-abundant thin-film solar cells as a sustainable solar energy pathway
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Sustainable Energy pathways (SEP) Program, under the umbrella of the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability (SEES) initiative, will support the research program of Prof. Yanfa Yan and co-workers at the University of Toledo. The highly multi-disciplinary research team consists of experts in physics, materials science, engineering, chemistry, socioeconomics, environmental science, and education. The objective of the project is to develop the concepts, materials, and processes necessary to economically produce environmentally friendly thin-film solar cells from earth-abundant, environmentally benign (EAEB) materials including FeS2, Cu2S, CuO, Zn3P2 and Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS). To achieve high efficiency EAEB solar cells, the research team proposes two new concepts: (1) a bulk homojunction for EAEB inorganic materials that have low carrier mobility and low structural stability (e.g., for FeS2, Cu2S, and CuO) and (2) a hetero-homo dual-junction (HHDJ) for Zn3P2- and CZTS-based thin-film solar cells. The bulk homojunction concept will be realized by assembling nanocrystals (NCs) with surfaces that will be carefully engineered to contain cation-rich domains. Upon assembly, the NCs will form a three-dimensional interconnected network of electron and hole channels that can facilitate charge separation and transfer with minimal efficiency-robbing recombination due to the homojunction topology. The HHDJ will be achieved by accurate control of the junction chemistry using dedicated physical vapor deposition systems with in situ monitoring, including real-time electron impact emission spectroscopy and real-time spectroscopic ellipsometry. The HHDJ concept combines the benefits of the heterojunction and the homojunction: the homojunction minimizes efficiency-robbing recombination while the heterojunction enhances the charge separation and transfer, leading to optimal solar cell performance.

The research team will concomitantly develop and analyze the sustainability of our new solar cell systems and manufacturing processes through life cycle tools where life cycle costing (LCC), environmental life cycle assessment (LCA), and social life cycle assessment (SLCA) will be developed simultaneously to create a comprehensive life cycle sustainability assessment (LCSA). To implement LCSA, a new dynamic approach will be used whereby different scenarios will be iteratively modeled to identify the specific interactions of the parameters and, ultimately, the most sustainable scenarios. To address education/workforce development, the research team will target critical educational goals for students at all levels. The research team will also employ an integrative approach wherein students from widely varying backgrounds and fields of expertise will work together to solve complex real world problems. This approach will further reinforce synergy, broaden educational goals, and build a true team philosophy.

This project will yield at least two scientific impacts: (1) a thorough understanding of the fundamental science and engineering issues that are critical for realizing a sustainable solar energy pathway using non-toxic and earth-abundant materials, and (2) new science and education paradigms for designing economically, environmentally, and socially sustainable renewable energy and, specifically, solar electricity pathways. By directly integrating the needs of society and industry in developing the materials and engineering technology, this project should serve as a transformational model for the sustainable development of new renewable energy technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit 

Thrust 1: Scientific and technological innovation in earth abundant thin-film solar cells.

We have developed new processes, based on both vacuum and solution methods, to synthesize uniform thin layers of a large number of earth abundant light-absorbing and electrode materials, including Zn3P2, CuSbS2, Cu2ZnSnS4, Cu2BaZnSnS4, CuxS, FeS2, CoFeS2, CuFeS2,  amorphous Si:H, and metal halide perovskites. The processing methods include close space sublimation, R.F. magnetron sputtering, thermal evaporation, chemical bath deposition, atomic-layer deposition, spray pyrolysis, colloidal synthesis, spin coating, dip coating. These new processes open-up considerable promise for earth abundant thin-film solar cells. We also developed methods to successfully synthesize and stabilize molecular silver nanoparticles (MNPs). We have also developed post-deposition treatments, such as sulfurization, selenization, solvent annealing to improve the quality of the absorber layers. We performed experiments to thoroughly understand the mechanism of grain nucleation and growth and developed approaches to control grain growth. Furthermore, we have developed methods to fabricate thin film solar cells using these absorber materials.

We also developed several advanced methods to evaluate the properties of the absorber and interface materials, and to assess the performance of the fabricated PV solar cells. We developed and optimized real time spectroscopic ellipsometry methods to study the growth of absorber layers as well the formation of phase-segregated material. We adopted this method to monitor in situ the growth of both absorber and interface layers.  We developed light-beam induced current (LBIC) imaging method to study the evolution of absorber materials and the degradation paths of thin-film solar cells during stress tests. We have also developed a circuit model to understand the S-kink distorted current-voltage curves seen in many thin-film solar cells. 

 

Thrust 2:  Sustainability assessment of the photovoltaic technology and products

Prior to this grant the environmental assessment of emerging solar PV technologies were very limited. We first reviewed the environmental impacts and energy payback times of existing commercial technologies. Then, creating the bridge between materials science and sustainability fields, we developed the very first life cycle environmental inventories for the new types of single junction and two terminal tandem solar cells including those made from carbon nanotube, perovskite, perovskite-tandem, and CZTS, and zinc phosphide absorber layers.  In these life cycle assessment studies, we analyzed different types of environmental impacts (e.g. global warming, human toxicity, ecological toxicity, and ozone depletion) but to allow for easier interpretation we suggested that the impacts be normalized to those of mono crystalline Si solar cells that currently dominate 90 % of the market. Apart from normalizing the environmental impacts to those of crystalline Si, we also analyzed and presented the findings in terms of energy payback time (EPBT) and primary energy demand (PED). All these studies showed that the environmental impacts from emerging solar technologies depend largely on the cell efficiency and the lifetime of the modules but in general, the emerging technologies had lower environmental impacts partly due to the layers being deposited using solution-based methods.

Another new research area that emerged from our work was the estimation of the potential release of toxic metals from damaged PV cells. While this is not a concern for existing technologies, the use of solution-based methods brings the possibility for metals to be more easily released to the environment. To evaluate this concern, we did a broad analysis for six metals (cadmium, copper, lead, nickel, tin and zinc) that are commonly used in thin film solar cells. We developed a new model that incorporates field conditions (crack size, time, glass thickness) and physiochemical properties (diffusion coefficient and solubility product). In comparing the toxic metal releases from solar cells to today's coal power plants, we also found that the metal emissions from PVs are expected to be several times less than the emissions from coal.

 

Broader of impacts

Social impacts of photovoltaic technology. We developed a social handprint/footprint (SH/F) reporting framework for thin film solar cells. The framework was developed to incorporate two approaches—scale-based and quantitative approach—to be consistent with current product Social Life Cycle Assessment (S-LCA) methodologies.

A New Module to Train the Next Generation Solar Workforce on the Sustainability of Photovoltaic Technology. We created curriculum on the integration of materials synthesis, device fabrication, and LCA analysis for training next generation solar workforce on the sustainability of PV technologies.

Student training. We trained 12 PhD, 7 MS, 12 undergrad and 13 high school students in solar energy research. We also did multiple solar energy outreach presentations to Hispanic and African American middle school students. We also reinvested in UT’s RISE program (Research in Science and Engineering) and connected high school students with the NSF-sponsored research efforts. Approximately 22 students came to UT over the summers (~6-8 weeks) to do research with UT scientists. Many of these students were from underrepresented groups.

Publications. We have published more than 100 peer-reviewed journal articles.
